article.headline: UNLV 78, New Mexico 75
article.story: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) -- UNLV junior Odartey Blankson is a problem solver. Plagued by too many turnovers and caught in a fast-paced shootout Monday with New Mexico, the Rebels turned the versatile forward loose and he responded with a career-high 28 points and 12 rebounds in UNLV's 78-75 win over the Lobos. Blankson scored 11 straight points late in the second half and broke New Mexico with his assortment of 3-pointers, inside jumpers and bank shots. He hit 11 of 17 shots and was four-of-four on 3-pointers in the second half. Together with point guard Jerel Blassingame's 13 assists, it was enough to make up for UNLV's 18 turnovers and sometimes poor shot selection. "The team did a fine job of finding me," said Blankson. "A lot of teams dare me to beat them from outside, but tonight the shots fell for me." "We couldn't account for Blankson hitting four of four from beyond the arc, he hasn't done that all year," New Mexico Coach Ritchie McKay said. "To his credit, he stepped up and made some big plays and made some big shots." Blankson's scoring spree in a span of less than three minutes put the Rebels (16-10, 7-6 MWC) over the top in the up-tempo game that saw the teams combine for 18 3-pointers while putting up 125 shots. UNLV held off New Mexico (14-12, 5-8) behind Blassingame's five straight points inside of two minutes and Demetrius Hunter's two free throws with 17.9 seconds left. Hunter's free throws, which followed an off-balance 3-pointer by New Mexico's Javin Tindall with 18.7 seconds left that cut the Rebels' lead to 76-75, were the last points of the game. New Mexico put up three 3-pointers in the final seconds, but all missed. Troy DeVries' 3 rimmed out, and teammate Danny Granger rebounded the miss and passed it to an open Tindall at the top of the key. Tindall's 3-pointer also rimmed out, but again Granger got the rebound. With only a couple of seconds left, Granger dribbled out to behind the arc and put a 3 at the buzzer that sailed long. "Troy with a good look, I'll take any day of the week," McKay said. "Then Javin got a look and Danny had the presence of mind to step behind the arc and try another one. But it didn't go in." Granger led New Mexico with 23 points and 9 rebounds. Tindall added 17 points and a career-high 5 steals. New Mexico took a 64-62 lead after Rebels center J.K. Edwards fouled out with 5:56 left and the UNLV bench was assessed a technical foul for protesting the call. Tindall hit one of the two technical foul shots and Granger, who was fouled by Edwards, hit both of his free throws. Blankson, who had given UNLV a 62-61 lead with a basket moments earlier, then took over. He hit a 15-footer, a layup, a 3-pointer and another 15-footer for a 71-68 UNLV lead with 3:41 remaining. After Tindall's late 3-pointer, Hunter was fouled on the inbound play. He swished through both free throws, his only points of the game. UNLV is 4-1 since former assistant Jay Spoonhour took over from his dad, Charlie Spoonhour last month. The elder Spoonhour resigned for health reasons. "They're playing free and easy right now," McKay said. "Those shots weren't taken when they played under Charlie, so they have a coach that's going a great job with them, because that's how that team has to play to have success."
